Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
We present here the fabrication of suspended hafnium oxide (HfO
$$_{2})$$
2
)
photonic crystal slab on a III-nitride/Si platform. The calculations are performed to model the suspended HfO
$$_{2 }$$
2
photonic crystal slab. Aluminum nitride (AlN) film is employed as the sacrificial layer to form air gap. Photonic crystal patterns are defined by electron beam lithography and transferred into HfO
$$_{2 }$$
2
film, and suspended HfO
$$_{2 }$$
2
photonic crystal slab is achieved on a III-nitride/Si platform through wet-etching of AlN layer in the alkaline solution. The method is promising for the fabrication of suspended HfO
$$_{2 }$$
2
nanostructures incorporating into a III-nitride/Si platform, or acting as the template for epitaxial growth of III-nitride materials.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Recently, considerable efforts have been made to incorporate suspended nanostructures into one surface emitting device. Since the suspended nanostructures are often sandwiched with air as low refractive index material on the top and bottom, the large refractive index difference endows the nanostructures the capacity to function as guided-mode resonant optical filter or reflection mirror [1–5]. Using single layer InP photonic crystal mirror, Boutami et al. [6] realized compact and polarization controlled 1.55
$${\upmu }$$
μ
m vertical-cavity surface emitting laser. Huang et al. [7] presented a surface emitting laser incorporating a single layer Al
$$_{0.6}$$
0.6
Ga
$$_{0.4}$$
0.4
as subwavelength grating. Kim et al. [8] fabricated freestanding AlGaN membrane grating reflector in the visible range. Suspended nanostructures also improve the cavity confinement. Arita et al. [9] reported Aluminum nitride (AlN) air-bridge photonic crystal cavities with embedded GaN quantum dots, and Lin et al. [10] demonstrated a GaN photonic crystal membrane laser. Moreover, suspended nanostructures are compact with high reflectivity and feasible to be coupled to a microelectromechanical system for tunable optical devices [11, 12].

Here, we focus on the development of integrated optical devices on a III-nitride/Si substrate. Compared to SiC and sapphire substrates, the backside process for a silicon substrate is available. The III-nitride/Si platform is quite attractive for further integration with silicon micromachining process and large-scale commercial applications. Suspended hafnium oxide (HfO
$$_{2})$$
2
)
nanostructures are proposed to be incorporated into this material platform. HfO
$$_{2}$$
2
film is an excellent optical material and transparent from the visible to infrared range [13]. It often acts as the high refractive index material in the multilayered stacks or the waveguiding structures [14–16]. Moreover, HfN film that can be generated by nitrifying HfO
$$_{2}$$
2
substrate is a promising template for the epitaxial growth of GaN with a small lattice mismatch of 0.35 % [17, 18]. Thus, HfO
$$_{2}$$
2
film is a potential buffer layer for epitaxial growth of GaN.

However, HfO
$$_{2}$$
2
film is difficult to etch, and usually serves as an etching mask. In our previous work, fast atom beam (FAB) etching of HfO
$$_{2}$$
2
film is developed to overcome this fabrication issue [19, 20]. Thanks to this unique manufacturing method, single layer freestanding HfO
$$_{2}$$
2
gratings are demonstrated with a stopband width of 40 nm at 1,520 nm. We are now interested in integrating it with the III-nitride/Si platform. The main applications of such structures are to replace the traditional top reflector, to fabricate resonant cavity surface emitting device, or to act as a template for epitaxial growth of III-nitride materials.

A microscope based micro-reflectance set up is used to characterize the micro-reflectance of the fabricated HfO
$$_{2}$$
2
photonic crystal slab. A xenon lamp is used as the broadband light source and the light is focused onto the sample surface. The reflected light is then collected off a beam splitter and coupled into an optical fiber which is connected to the Ocean Optics USB2000 spectrometer for analysis. Since the device region is small, a microscope objective lens with large numerical aperture (NA) is used to focus incident light on the sample, and a charge-coupled device camera is installed on the setup to acquire sample images. The experimental spectra illustrated in Fig. 4a are normalized to those of a commercial aluminum mirror. The fabricated HfO
$$_{2}$$
2
photonic crystal slabs are polarization independent under normal incidence due to the 90
$${^\circ }$$
∘
rotational symmetry of the square lattice. Trapezoidal air holes, 1.26
$${\upmu } $$
μ
m gap and 600 nm lattice constant are employed for simulation with a normal incidence. The measured reflectance peaks in comparison with the calculation shift and decrease from 100 % because the deviations take place between the photonic crystal slabs generated in reality and the ideal element. For example, the calculated resonances at 666.7 and 700.8 nm shift to 683.12 and 711.57 nm, respectively. Moreover, the reflection peaks include guided-mode resonances and multiple reflections in the back air gap, and become wider and slightly shift to shorter wavelengths as the NA increases. A collimated light beam incident to the photonic crystal could give rise to the resonance [22].The tightly focused light using large NA lens may not give the benefit of seeing the resonances.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para:
In summary, suspended HfO
$$_{2 }$$
2
photonic crystal slabs are achieved on a III-nitride/Si platform by a combination of film deposition, EB lithography, FAB etching of HfO
$$_{2}$$
2
film and wet-etching of AlN film. The suspended HfO
$$_{2 }$$
2
photonic crystal slabs are sandwiched with air as low refractive index material on the top and bottom, and guided-mode resonances are experimentally demonstrated by the reflectance measurements. The simple process is feasible to fabricate suspended HfO
$$_{2}$$
2
nanostructures on a III-nitride/Si platform, which are promising for further tunable III-nitride optical devices and integrated optics.
